Vocabularies.Definition: as far as ... is concerned 至于，就…来说
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The rise in interest rate will be disastrous in the case of small firms.

Vocabularies.Definition: prevent from doing sth. 挡道；妨碍
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Many teachers complain that they can't make any improvement in teaching methods as the existing exam system is in the way.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  保卫者
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. he had to beat several defenders to score.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  the ruler of an empire 皇帝；君主
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. the Roman emperors

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  one's native country 祖国；家乡
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Many emigrants are planning to return to their homeland.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. causing great destruction 毁灭性的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Thousands of refugees are trapped by devastating war, draught and famine.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. cold and wet; not cooked, refined, processed, organized or analyzed 阴冷的；生的；未加工的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The events took place on a raw February morning.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.  cold and miserable; depressing 寒冷刺骨的；凄凉的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The streets are deserted on a bleak winter morning.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt. start; send (sth.) on its course 开始；发射
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Beginning in the early 1960s, humans launched probes to explore other planets.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. superior to all others 无比的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Though small, this restaurant offers a range of fish dishes unequaled anywhere else in London.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  a series of military operations or planned activities with a particular aim 战役；运动
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Some people complained that too much money had been spent on political campaigns.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. the line dividing two countries or areas; the land near this line 边界（地区）
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The terrorists escaped across the border.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.  able to work well or producing a satisfactory result without wasting time or resources 效率高的 e.g. Remote terminals in the home, connected to data banks, make the home the most efficient place to work in many cases.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  conquering, defeat 征服，战胜 e.g. Hitler badly miscalculated when he assumed the conquest of the USSR would be simple.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.  producing a definite result or conclusion; having or showing the ability to decide quickly 决定性的；果断的 e.g. Most of the decisive land campaigns of World War I occurred on the continent of Europe.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: vi.  move back or withdraw when faced with danger or difficulty 退却 n. e.g. We adopted the following strategies: When the enemy advances, we retreat: when they retreat, we pursue.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: v. (cause to) become stuck and unable to make progress （使）陷入泥潭；阻碍 be/get bogged down be unable to make progress 陷入泥潭；不能前进 e.g. Most of the tanks were bogged down because of mechanical defects and inexperienced crews.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: v.  begin fighting with sb.; (cause to) take part in or do; occupy or attract sb.'s interest, etc. 与…交战；使从事；占用（时间、精力等） engage (sb.) in sth. (cause to) take part in sth.（使）（某人）从事某事 e.g. They are currently engaged in lengthy trade negotiations.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: have to deal with 面临；要对付 e.g. The librarians were faced with the huge task of listing all the books.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.  very important 至关重要的 e.g. Amazingly, our soccer team won the victory in the crucial final game.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  a thing one does with a risk of loss and a chance of profit 赌博 take a gamble take a risk 冒险 e.g. The company took a gamble by cutting the price of their products, and it paid off.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: continue doing sth. in a determined way （不顾困难）继续进行
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Our school authorities are keen to press on with educational reform.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. dusk 黄昏；傍晚
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. We hope to be back by nightfall.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. the seizure and control of a country or areas; (one's) trade, profession, or business 占领；职业
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. During the Japanese occupation of China, millions of innocent Chinese people were killed by Japanese soldiers.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. an agreement to stop fighting 停战
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.  The fighting of recent days has given way to a truce between the two sides.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. 沙皇
v.  (arch) wait （除下列习语外，已不通用） 等待 bide one's time wait patiently for a chance 等待时机
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. His political rivals are biding their time for an attack on his policies.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. hitting and then escaping 打了就跑的
prep. below zero; made less by 零下；减 a. negative; slightly lower than the mark stated 负的；减的；稍低的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Tomorrow's temperature will be as low as minus ten degrees centigrade.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.  （温度）摄氏（的）
n. 大炮；火炮；机关炮
move slowly and with effort; continue endlessly and tediously 缓慢费力地走；拖延
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. These compensation cases have already dragged on for one year.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. grown bigger, wider, etc. than usual; expanded 涨水的；肿胀的；扩大的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The doctor says I've got swollen glands.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  一次；一回；一下；一击
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. He won a car in the lottery last week. That's his first stroke of good luck.

Vocabularies.Definition: with the loss of 以…代价
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The local government developed its economy but at the cost of environment.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. wearing torn and ragged clothes 衣衫褴褛的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. A tattered flag fluttered in the breeze.

Vocabularies.Definition: vi. walk with difficulty, esp. when one foot or leg is hurt 一瘸一拐地走；跛行 n.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. I injured my ankle and had to limp.

Vocabularies.Definition: v. (cause to) become weak or weaker （使）虚弱；（使）变弱
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The Asian financial crisis severely weakened some countries.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. 联盟
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. NATO is considered as the most powerful military alliance in modern history.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. 落伍士兵；掉队者
v.  resign from being king, emperor, etc. 退位
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. When King George abdicated, his brother succeeded him on the throne.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. the state of being sent away from one's native country or home, esp. for political reasons; forced absence 流放；流亡 vt.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. He lived in exile for nearly six years.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. 纳粹，国社党分子
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The Nazis were members of the right-wing National Socialist German Workers' Party, founded in Germany in 1919 and brought to power in 1933 under Adolf Hitler.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. an entering or being entered by an attacking military force 入侵；侵略
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. On Hitler's orders, the invasion of Poland began on September 1, 1939.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. 帝国
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. the Roman Empire

Vocabularies.Definition: n. formally announcing; a formal announcement 宣布；宣言
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The opening speeches sounded more like declarations of war than offerings of peace.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. a concentrated military campaign intended to win a quick victory 闪电战
n. soft wet earth 烂泥
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The car got stuck in the mud.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. very quick or sudden 闪电式的，极快的 n. 闪电
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Police made a lightning raid on the house.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. (usu. pl) a plan or method used to achieve sth. often against an opponent 战术
take sb. by surprise 乘某人不备
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The manager didn't know what to say. It was clear that my question had caught him off guard.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt.  give orders or directions to (sb.); teach (sb.) 指示，命令；讲授
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The family has instructed solicitors to sue Thomson for compensation.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt. burn and destroy; cause to become dry and brown, esp. from the heat of the sun 烧光，使成焦土；烤焦
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. I scorched my dress with the iron.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt. cause (sb./sth.) to be in a specified condition 使成为
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Hundreds of people were rendered homeless by the earthquake.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. 德国人；德语 a. 德国（人）的
n. a person who is killed or injured in war or in an accident 伤亡人员；死伤者
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The precise number of casualties in yesterday's bomb explosion is not known.

Vocabularies.Definition: have as the cause of death 死于
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Some animals died of starvation in the snow.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. a military operation in which an army tries to capture a town, etc. by surrounding it and stopping the supply of food, etc. to the people inside 围困
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The city was under siege for six months.

Vocabularies.Definition: stop completely 使停止
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Air traffic in Poland had been brought to a halt by an air traffic controllers' strike.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. aggressive action, attack 进攻 a. used for or connected with attack; causing sb. to feel upset, or annoyed; very unpleasant 进攻的；冒犯的；使人不快的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The Red Army brought its winter offensive to a successful conclusion.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  attack made in response to an enemy's attack 反攻
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The army began its counterattack this morning.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. (pl) (a body of) soldiers 部队

n.  a regular rise and fall in the level of the sea; a direction in which opinion, events, luck, etc. seem to move 潮汐；潮流，趋势 turn the tide (against) change what looks like defeat into victory (over) 彻底改变形势（造成对…不利），扭转潮流
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The tide of opinion seemed to be turned against them.

Vocabularies.Definition: because of 由于，因为
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Thanks to her financial support, the two children in the remote village could go to school.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. having the characteristics of a hero; very brave 英雄的；英勇的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The soldier saved the girl at the cost of his own life. His heroic deeds were appreciated by all the people in the community.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. area 地区
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. When examining a large geographic unit, geographers often divide it into smaller regions.

Vocabularies.Definition: v. count; consider; think 计算；认为 be reckoned with be taken into consideration 被加以考虑
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. All these problems had to be reckoned with as they arose.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt.  set too low an estimate on or for 低估
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Never underestimate your opponent.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. the quality of being severe; harshness 猛烈；严重
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The broken windows and doors of the house added to the severity of the winter.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. the number of people or animals killed or injured in particular circumstances; money paid for the use of a bridge or road 伤亡人数；（道路、桥梁）通行费 take its/a toll cause damage, injuries or deaths 造成损失（伤亡等）
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The famine took a toll of 3,000,000 lives.
